variant.title: Discovering contradicting protein-protein interactions in text
variant.author: Olivia Sanchez-Graillet
variant.affiliation: Univ. of Essex, Wivenhoe Park, Colches-
variant.bodyText: In biomedical texts, contradictions about protein- protein interactions (PPIs) occur when an author reports observing a given PPI whereas another au- thor argues that very same interaction does not take place: e.g., when author X argues that “protein A interacts with protein B” whereas author Y claims that “protein A does not interact with B”. Of course, merely discovering a potential contradic- tion does not mean the argument is closed as other factors may have caused the proteins to behave in different ways. We present preliminary work to- wards the automatic detection of potential contra- dictions between PPIs from text and an agreement experimental evaluation of our method.

Our method consists of the following steps: i) ex- tract positive and negative cases of PPIs and map them to a semantic structure; ii) compare the pairs of PPIs structures that contain similar canonical protein names iii) apply an inference method to the selected pair of PPIs. We extract positive and negative cases of PPIs by applying our system (Sanchez & Poesio, sub- mitted). Our system considers proteins only as well as events where only one protein participates (e.g. “PI-3K activity”). The system produces the seman- tic interpretation shown in Table 1. We manually corrected some of the information extracted in or- der to compare exclusively our inference method with human annotators. The decision to determine if a C-PPI holds is given by the context. This context is formed by the combination of semantic components such as PPI polarity, verb direction, and manner polarity.

Univ. of Essex, Wivenhoe Park, Col- chester CO4 3SQ, U.K. DIT and Center for Mind/Brain Sci- ences, Univ. of Trento, Via Sommarive 14 I-38050 POVO (TN) - Italy poesio@essex.ac.uk Canonical name of the first participant protein Canonical name of the second participant protein. Word (verbs or their nominalizations) expressing a PPI (e.g. interact, interaction, activate, activation, etc.). Categories in which cue-words are grouped according to their similar effect in an interaction. (See Table 2). Whether the PPI is positive or negative Direction of a relation according to the effect that a protein causes on other molecules in the interaction. (See Table 3) Modality expressed by adverbs or adjectives (e.g. directly, weakly, strong, etc.) Polarity assigned to manner according to the influence they have on the cue-word (see Table 4)
variant.tableCaption: Table 1. Semantic structure of a PPI
variant.table: Semantic Rela- Verbs/nouns examples tion Activate Activat (e, ed,es,or,ion), transactivat (e,ed,es,ion) Inactivate decreas (e,ed,es), down-regulat(e,ed,es,ion)
variant.tableCaption: Table 2. Example of semantic verb relations
variant.table: + - Neutral Activate, Attach Inactivate Substitute, React Create bond Break bond Modify, Cause Generate Release Signal, Associate
Polarity Word (+) 1 strong(ly), direct(ly), potential(y), rapid(ly) (-) 0 hardly, indirect(ly), negative(e,ly)
variant.bodyText: Manner polarity is neutral (2) if the manner word is not included in the manner polarity table or if no manner word affects the cue-word. The method first obtains what we call “PPI state” of each PPI. The PPI state is obtained in two steps that follow decision tables1: a) the values for
variant.figure: 1 Some decision tables are omitted due to space reasons. P1 P2 Cue-word Semantic Relation Polarity Direction Manner Manner Polarity
variant.subsubsectionHeader: BioNLP 2007: Biological, translational, and clinical language processing, pages 195–196,
variant.bodyText: Prague, June 2007. c�2007 Association for Computational Linguistics the combination of the verb direction and the man- ner polarity (DM) of each PPI; b) then, the DM value and the polarity of the corresponding PPI are evaluated. Second, the method compares the PPI states of both PPIs as shown in Table 5.
variant.table: State1 Sstate2 Result State1 State2 Result 0 0 NC 3 3 U 0 1 C 0 4 C 0 3 U 1 4 C 1 1 NC 3 4 C 1 3 U
variant.bodyText: The following example illustrates our method. The table below shows two sentences taken from dif- ferent documents.
variant.figure: PPIA state PPIB state Result -(0) NN (4) Contradiction The result obtained is “Contradiction”.
variant.bodyText: As a way of evaluation, we compared agreement between our method and human annotators by us- ing the kappa measure (Siegel and Castellan, 1998). We elaborated a test containing only of 31 pairs of sentences (JBC articles) since this task can be tiring for human annotators. The test consisted on classifying the pairs of sentences into three categories: contradiction (C), no contradiction (NC) and unsure (U). The values of kappa obtained are presented in the following table.
variant.table: Document 1 Document 2 And fourth, C2- ceramide did not affect the amount of PI 3-kinase activity in anti-IRS-1 precipi- tates. Groups Kappa Biologists only 0.37 Biologists and our method 0.37 Non-biologists only 0.22 Non-biologists and our method 0.19
variant.bodyText: Cells treated with hyperosmolar stress, UV-C, IR, or a cell-permeable form of ceramide, C2 ceramide, rapidly down- regulated PI(3)K activity to 10%-30% of the activity found in serum-stimulated control cells... The semantic structures corresponding to these sentences are shown in the next table.
variant.table: DocA DocB P1 C2-ceramide C2-ceramide P2 PI-3K PI-3K Cue down-regulate affect Semantic relation Inactivate Cause Polarity positive negative Direction negative neutral Manner rapidly -- Manner polarity positive neutral
variant.bodyText: The decision tables produced for this example are the following3.
variant.figure: PPI Direction Manner DM A - (0) + (1) - (0) B N (2) N (2) U (3) PPI Polarity DM State A + (1) - (0) - (0) B - (0) U(3) NN (4)
variant.footnote: 2 Result values: contradiction (C), no contradiction (NC) and unsure (U). 3 The values included in the tables are: positive=1, nega- tive=0, neutral=2, unsure=3, and negative-neutral=4.
variant.bodyText: Biologists mainly justified their answers based on biological knowledge (e.g. methodology, organ- isms, etc.) while non-biologists based their answers on syntax.

We have presented a simple method to detect po- tential contradictions of PPIs by using context ex- pressed by semantics and linguistics constituents (e.g. modals, verbs, adverbs, etc). Our method showed to perform similarly to biologists and bet- ter than non-biologists. Interestingly, biologists concluded that C-PPIs are rarely found; neverthe- less, the cases found may be highly significant. Continuing with our work, we will try our sys- tem in a larger set of data.
variant.reference: Sanchez,O and Poesio,M. (Submitted). Negation of pro- tein-protein interactions: analysis and extraction. Siegel, S. and Castellan, N.J. (1998). Nonparametric statistics for the behavioral sciences. 2nd. edition, McGraw-Hill.
